en: Interview with Carey Woods, 2020-01-11

Interview with Carey Woods, principle of Pi Beta Phi Elementary School during the wildfire. Woods recounts the time leading up to the fire and the decisions she made for students' safety. She also recounts the evacuation of the school to Rocky Top Sports World in response to the severity of the smoke and the difficulties faced in the following months with relocating students and faculty to different schools. This is a representative quote from the interview: "My concern was, how many of my students have just lost everything? How many of my students are alive and are not alive, and their families?"

Description

Interview with Carey Woods, principle of Pi Beta Phi Elementary School during the wildfire. Woods recounts the time leading up to the fire and the decisions she made for students' safety. She also recounts the evacuation of the school to Rocky Top Sports World in response to the severity of the smoke and the difficulties faced in the following months with relocating students and faculty to different schools. This is a representative quote from the interview: "My concern was, how many of my students have just lost everything? How many of my students are alive and are not alive, and their families?"

Bibliographic Description in MODS
Interview with Carey Woods, 2020-01-11
Interview Questions
Can you tell us your name and what brought you to Gatlinburg?
Can you tell us a little about the Pi Beta Phi school and where it is in Gatlinburg?
When did you become aware of the fire in the Smokies?
So you were keeping the children inside for recess the week before the fire? Can you tell me about the reaction you got?
What did it look like outside that week? Were you worried about anything besides the smoke?
What time of day did you start having conversations with the superintendent that Monday?
Where were you placing the students inside of the school?
Were parents calling or coming to pick up their students?
What time of day did you start evacuating the school to Rocky Top?
So who remained at the school after evacuating?
Did you still have power in the school?
When you left, what did it look like outside the school?
Was there any panic amongst the students?
When you released the teachers, did they go back to the school?
What time did you go back to the school?
Did you see any fire in Gatlinburg then?
Where is Sky Harbor in relation to the school?
Was the Sky Harbor fire the only one you could see?
Who is Mr. Reed?
When you first heard the school was on fire, what was your reaction?
And this was on Tuesday?
What was it about the second day that made the stress and emotions hgiher?
What do you see riding back to Pi Beta Phi?
What do you see riding back to Pi Beta Phi?
What else did yo usee inside the school?
When you came back, how many students did you have? Do you know why there was a drop off?
When did yo find out that two students had perished?
Did you have the conversation witht the fourth and sixth grade classes about the loss?
Can you give us a sense about what the recovery effort was like after you're back in the old George Pittman elementary school?
How did this fire shape community relations in Gatlinburg?
What was the first-hand emotional impact for you?
Was there anything surprising or good that came out of this disaster?
Is there anything that we haven't mentioned that you would like to share?
Do you think that we could have another fire?
